so_8399493: #!/bin/bash

# requirements for script script

COUNTER=$((7+1))
DATE=$(date -d "-${COUNTER} days" +%s)
DATE=$(date -d -@${DATE} "+%Y-%m-%d")

sed -i "1,/$DATE/d" test.txt

ul_468510: find . -type f -exec sh -c '
  h=$(date -d @$(stat -c %Y "$1") +%-H); [ "$h" -ge 11 ] && [ "$h" -lt 15 ]' \
  sh {} \; -ls

find . -type f -exec sh -c '
  h=$(date -d @$(stat -c %Y "$1") +%-H); [ "$h" -ge 11 ] && [ "$h" -lt 15 ]' \
  sh {} \; -delete

$ touch -d 'Wed Sep 12 11:00:01 EDT 2018' 11am
$ touch -d 'Wed Sep 12 12:00:02 EDT 2018' 12pm
$ touch -d 'Wed Sep 12 15:00:03 EDT 2018' 303pm
$ find . -type f -exec sh -c 'h=$(date -d @$(stat -c %Y "$1") +%-H); [ "$h" -ge 11 ] && [ "$h" -lt 15 ]' sh {} \; -ls
1705096    0 -rw-r--r--   1 user group 0 Sep 12  2018 ./11am
1705097    0 -rw-r--r--   1 user group 0 Sep 12  2018 ./12pm

date -d @ ... +%-H

Explanations about Options.-d: display time described by STRING, not 'now'

Answers.MP Summary: display an HFS directory in long format

so_20869207: Removing Columns From ALL CSV Files in Specific Folder Then Outputting File With Date
Top-3 Scripts:
so_20869207: #! /bin/bash

saveDir="saveCsv"
dd=$(date +%Y-%m-%d -d "yesterday")
for file in *.csv ; do
    bname=$(basename "$file" .csv)
    saveName="${saveDir}/${bname}-${dd}.csv"
    cut -d',' -f2,12 "$file" > "$saveName"
done

Explanations about Options.-d: parse STRING and use it instead of current time
Explanations about Options.-t:
STAMP
 use [[CC]YY]MMDDhhmm[.ss] instead of current time
